<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 297, 393, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 278, 905, 333]]<|/det|>
9702/22 February/March 2017 1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 375]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper. No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 386, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 767, 558]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 567, 760, 597]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 670, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 106, 561, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 527, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 193, 537, 223]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 235, 522, 252]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 262, 561, 293]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 305, 536, 321]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 339, 615, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - x^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 380, 537, 415]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu \pm \nu_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 425, 537, 460]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 467, 628, 486]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 500, 596, 520]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 530, 527, 556]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 570, 532, 588]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 603, 596, 622]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 637, 628, 655]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 668, 520, 702]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 715, 561, 733]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 749, 581, 768]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 777, 536, 812]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
Two blocks, A and B, are on a horizontal frictionless surface. The blocks are joined together by a spring, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 238, 806, 344]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 359, 480, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 390, 601, 409]]<|/det|>
Block A has mass \(4.0\mathrm{kg}\) and block B has mass \(6.0\mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 421, 843, 440]]<|/det|>
The variation of the tension \(F\) with the extension \(x\) of the spring is shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 450, 799, 693]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 710, 564, 728]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 777, 89]]<|/det|>
The two blocks are held apart so that the spring has an extension of \(8.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 181, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 900, 121]]<|/det|>
Show that the elastic potential energy of the spring at an extension of \(8.0 \text{cm}\) is \(0.48 \text{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 288, 920, 307]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 319, 181, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 319, 920, 354]]<|/det|>
The blocks are released from rest at the same instant. When the extension of the spring becomes zero, block A has speed \(v_{\mathrm{A}}\) and block B has speed \(v_{\mathrm{B}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 365, 715, 384]]<|/det|>
For the instant when the extension of the spring becomes zero,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 396, 598, 415]]<|/det|>
1. use conservation of momentum to show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 425, 628, 460]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\text{kinetic energy of block A}}{\text{kinetic energy of block B}} = 1.5\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 636, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 667, 223, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>2.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 667, 920, 715]]<|/det|>
use the information in **(b)(i)** and **(b)(ii)1** to determine the kinetic energy of block A. It may be assumed that the spring has negligible kinetic energy and that air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 852, 920, 871]]<|/det|>
<form>kinetic energy of block A = .................................................... J [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 504, 90]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 427, 703, 446]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 521, 848, 541]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 918, 106]]<|/det|>

The \(\alpha\)-particle emitted from the bismuth nucleus has an initial kinetic energy of \(9.3 \times 10^{-13} \text{J}\). As the \(\alpha\)-particle moves through air it causes the removal of electrons from atoms. The \(\alpha\)-particle loses energy and is stopped after removing \(1.8 \times 10^5\) electrons as it moved through the air.
